alert.title: For Grave and Imminent Emergencies Only!
alert.description: This format is for situations where there is a serious danger to a vessel or a person, and immediate help is required.

step1.title: MAYDAY, MAYDAY, MAYDAY:
step1.description: Repeat three times to make the distress signal unmistakable and grab immediate attention.

step2.title: THIS IS...
step2.description: Identify your vessel by repeating its name three times. This ensures there is no doubt about who is transmitting.

step3.title: CALL SIGN AND MMSI:
step3.description: Provide your call sign and MMSI number. They are crucial unique identifiers for rescue services.

step4.title: MAYDAY:
step4.description: Repeat the word one more time, followed by your ship's name, to reinforce the nature of the call.

step5.title: POSITION:
step5.description: Provide your location as accurately as possible (Latitude/Longitude or reference to a known point).

step6.title: NATURE OF DISTRESS:
step6.description: Briefly describe the emergency. E.g., 'we have a fire in the engine room', 'we are taking on water', 'we have collided with another vessel'.

step7.title: ASSISTANCE REQUIRED:
step7.description: Specify what kind of help you need. E.g., 'we require immediate assistance', 'we require a tug', 'we request medical evacuation'.

step8.title: PERSONS ON BOARD:
step8.description: Report the total number of people on your vessel. This is vital for rescue teams.

step9.title: OTHER INFORMATION:
step9.description: Add any relevant details that could help the rescue. E.g., 'vessel is sinking', 'we are wearing life jackets', 'abandoning ship in a life raft'.

step10.title: OVER:
step10.description: Indicates that you have finished your transmission, leaving the channel open to receive the response from the coast station or other vessels.

page.title: COLREG Study Guide
page.description: Summary of the Steering and Sailing Rules from the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREG).

rule1.title: Rule 1: Application
rule1.point1: Applies to all vessels in the high seas and connected waters.
rule1.point2: Does not interfere with special rules for roadsteads, harbours, rivers, etc.
rule1.point3: Does not interfere with special rules for lights, shapes, or signals for warships or convoys.
rule1.point4: Traffic separation schemes may be adopted by the Organization (IMO).
rule1.point5: A vessel of special construction may be exempted if it complies with the intent of the regulations.

rule2.title: Rule 2: Responsibility
rule2.point1: Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel, or the owner, master or crew thereof, from the consequences of any neglect.
rule2.point2: Account shall be taken of all dangers of navigation and collision.
rule2.point3: Departure from the Rules may be made to avoid immediate danger.

rule3.title: Rule 3: General Definitions
rule3.subpoint1: 'Vessel' includes every description of water craft, including non-displacement craft and seaplanes.
rule3.subpoint2: 'Power-driven vessel' means any vessel propelled by machinery.
rule3.subpoint3: 'Sailing vessel' means any vessel under sail provided that propelling machinery, if fitted, is not being used.
rule3.subpoint4: 'Vessel engaged in fishing' means any vessel fishing with nets, lines, etc. which restrict maneuverability.
rule3.subpoint5: 'Vessel not under command' (NUC) means a vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to maneuver.
rule3.subpoint6: 'Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver' (RAM) means a vessel which from the nature of her work is restricted in her ability to maneuver.
rule3.subpoint7: 'Vessel constrained by her draught' means a power-driven vessel which because of her draught is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from the course she is following.
rule3.subpoint8: 'Underway' means that a vessel is not at anchor, or made fast to the shore, or aground.

partB.title: Part B - Steering and Sailing Rules

section1.title: Section I - Conduct of vessels in any condition of visibility

rule5.title: Rule 5: Look-out
rule5.point1: Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing.
rule5.point2: Use all available means (radar, VHF, etc.).
rule5.point3: Appraise the situation and risk of collision.

rule6.title: Rule 6: Safe Speed
rule6.point1: Every vessel shall at all times proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action to avoid collision.
rule6.point2: Factors to be taken into account: visibility, traffic density, maneuverability, background lights, state of wind and sea, and draught.

rule7.title: Rule 7: Risk of Collision
rule7.point1: Every vessel shall use all available means to determine if risk of collision exists. If in doubt, risk shall be deemed to exist.
rule7.point2: Proper use shall be made of radar equipment (bearings and distances).
rule7.point3: Assumptions shall not be made on the basis of scanty information. Risk exists if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.

rule8.title: Rule 8: Action to Avoid Collision
rule8.point1: Action shall be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to good seamanship.
rule8.point2: Any alteration of course or speed shall be large enough to be readily apparent to another vessel.
rule8.point3: If there is sufficient sea room, alteration of course alone may be the most effective action.
rule8.point4: Action taken shall result in passing at a safe distance.

rule9.title: Rule 9: Narrow Channels
rule9.point1: A vessel proceeding along a narrow channel shall keep to the outer limit on her starboard side.
rule9.point2: A vessel of less than 20m or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can only safely navigate within the channel.
rule9.point3: A vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if it impedes the passage of others.
rule9.point4: The overtaking signal in a channel is ▬ ▬ ● (to starboard) or ▬ ▬ ● ● (to port). The overtaken vessel responds with ▬ ● ▬ ● if in agreement.

rule10.title: Rule 10: Traffic Separation Schemes (TSS)
rule10.point1: A vessel using a TSS shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane.
rule10.point2: So far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
rule10.point3: Normally join or leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane, but when joining or leaving from either side, do so at as small an angle as practicable.
rule10.point4: Avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so, cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.

section2.title: Section II - Conduct of vessels in sight of one another

rule12.title: Rule 12: Sailing Vessels
rule12.point1: When two sailing vessels are approaching one another, one of them shall keep out of the way of the other:
rule12.point2: When each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way.
rule12.point3: When both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward.

rule13.title: Rule 13: Overtaking
rule13.point1: Any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken.
rule13.point2: A vessel shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam.

rule14.title: Rule 14: Head-on Situation
rule14.point1: When two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses, each shall alter her course to starboard.

rule15.title: Rule 15: Crossing Situation
rule15.point1: When two power-driven vessels are crossing, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way.

rule16.title: Rule 16: Action by Give-way Vessel
rule16.point1: Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action.

rule17.title: Rule 17: Action by Stand-on Vessel
rule17.point1: The stand-on vessel shall keep her course and speed. She may, however, take action to avoid collision if it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

rule18.title: Rule 18: Responsibilities Between Vessels
rule18.point1: A power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of: a vessel not under command (NUC), a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (RAM), a vessel engaged in fishing, a sailing vessel.

section3.title: Section III - Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility

rule19.title: Rule 19: Conduct in Restricted Visibility
rule19.point1: This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another. Proceed at a safe speed.
rule19.point2: A vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a risk exists. Avoid altering course to port for a vessel forward of the beam (except for a vessel being overtaken).

rule20.title: Rule 20: Application
rule20.point1: Rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise. They may also be exhibited in restricted visibility.

rule21-31.title: Rules 21 to 31
rule21-31.point1: These rules define the types of lights (masthead, sidelights, sternlight), their arcs of visibility, and the specific combinations of lights and shapes for each type of vessel (power-driven, towing, sailing, fishing, NUC, RAM, etc.).

partD.title: Part D - Sound and Light Signals

rule32-37.title: Rules 32 to 37
rule32-37.point1: Define maneuvering and warning signals (short and long blasts), sound signals in restricted visibility (bell and gong), and distress signals.

partEF.title: Parts E & F - Exemptions and Verification

rule38.title: Rule 38: Exemptions
rule38.point1: Allows vessels built before the regulations came into force not to have to change the position of their lights.

rule39-41.title: Rules 39 to 41: Verification
rule39-41.point1: These rules cover the implementation and verification of compliance with the provisions of the convention. (Not typically part of PER exams).

lights.pdv_lights_making_way: In addition to the lights for a power-driven vessel making way.
lights.nuc_lights: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
lights.ram_lights: Three all-round lights (red, white, red) in a vertical line.
lights.cbd_lights: Three all-round red lights in a vertical line.

marks.trawl_mark: Two cones with their apexes together.
marks.nuc_marks: Two balls in a vertical line.
marks.ram_marks: Ball, diamond, and ball in a vertical line.
marks.aground_marks: Three balls in a vertical line.

R23.title: R23: Power-driven Vessels Underway
R23.description: Lights for a vessel > 50m in length.
R23.explanation: Masthead lights indicate the presence and direction of a power-driven vessel. The second masthead light, higher and aft, is mandatory for vessels 50m or more, and helps estimate its size and course.

R24.title: R24: Towing and Pushing
R24.description: Lights and shapes for vessels in towing operations.

towing_gt200.title: Towing, tow > 200m
towing_gt200.description: Towing astern, and the length of the tow (from the stern of the towing vessel to the stern of the tow) exceeds 200m.
towing_gt200.explanation: Three masthead lights in a vertical line indicate a tow longer than 200m. The yellow towing light is above the sternlight to avoid confusion with another masthead light seen from astern.

towing_lt200.title: Towing, tow < 200m
towing_lt200.description: Towing astern, length of tow is less than 200m.
towing_lt200.explanation: Two masthead lights in a vertical line indicate a towing operation. The diamond shape is not exhibited because the tow is less than 200m.

pushing.title: Pushing ahead
pushing.description: A vessel or group of vessels being pushed ahead, rigidly connected in a composite unit.
pushing.explanation: When rigidly connected, they are regarded as a single power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights for such.

R25.title: R25: Sailing Vessels and Vessels Under Oars
R25.description: Lights for a sailing vessel underway.
R25.explanation: Sailing vessels exhibit sidelights and a sternlight. Optionally, they can show two all-round lights at the masthead (red over green). By day, if also propelled by machinery, they must show a cone, apex downwards.

R26.title: R26: Fishing Vessels
R26.description: Lights and shapes for vessels engaged in fishing.

trawling.title: Engaged in trawling
trawling.description: A vessel engaged in trawling (dragging a net through the water).
trawling.explanation: Green over white, 'trawling at night'. These lights indicate the vessel is severely restricted in its ability to maneuver due to its nets.

fishing_not_trawling.title: Fishing (other than trawling)
fishing_not_trawling.description: A vessel engaged in fishing, but not trawling (e.g. long-lining, purse seining).
fishing_not_trawling.explanation: Red over white, 'fishing at night'. Indicates the vessel is fishing and its maneuverability is restricted by its gear.

R27.title: R27: Vessels Not Under Command or Restricted in Ability to Manoeuvre
R27.description: Lights for vessels that are unable to maneuver.

nuc.title: Not Under Command (NUC)
nuc.description: A vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to maneuver.
nuc.explanation: Two all-round red lights indicate 'not under command'. If making way, she must also show sidelights and a sternlight.

ram.title: Restricted in Ability to Manoeuvre (RAM)
ram.description: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver by the nature of her work (dredging, diving, etc.).
ram.explanation: Red, white, red in a vertical line. If there is an obstruction, two red lights are shown on the obstructed side and two green lights on the safe side.

R28.title: R28: Vessels Constrained by their Draught
R28.description: A power-driven vessel which because of her draught is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from her course.
R28.explanation: In addition to the normal lights of a power-driven vessel, she may exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line, or a cylinder. This is not a 'privilege' signal, but a warning to other vessels.

R30.title: R30: Anchored Vessels and Vessels Aground
R30.description: Lights and shapes for vessels not underway.

anchored.title: Anchored
anchored.description: A vessel at anchor, not aground.
anchored.explanation: An all-round white light forward (and another aft if > 50m) to indicate its position. By day, a black ball forward.

aground.title: Aground
aground.description: A vessel which is aground on a shoal or on the coast.
aground.explanation: She shall exhibit the lights for a vessel at anchor and, in addition, two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate she is aground and a danger to navigation.

R29.title: R29: Pilot Vessels
R29.explanation: White over red, 'pilot ahead'. These lights are in addition to the lights for a vessel of her length.

maneuver_stbd.title: Altering course to starboard
maneuver_stbd.description: A power-driven vessel underway, when maneuvering as authorized or required.

maneuver_port.title: Altering course to port
maneuver_port.description: A power-driven vessel underway, when maneuvering as authorized or required.

maneuver_astern.title: Operating astern propulsion
maneuver_astern.description: A power-driven vessel underway, when her engines are going astern.

overtake_stbd.title: Intend to overtake on starboard side
overtake_stbd.description: Signal to indicate the intention to overtake another vessel on her starboard side.

overtake_port.title: Intend to overtake on port side
overtake_port.description: Signal to indicate the intention to overtake another vessel on her port side.

overtake_agree.title: Agreement to be overtaken
overtake_agree.description: Reply from the vessel to be overtaken, if in agreement.

warning_doubt.title: Doubt / Warning signal
warning_doubt.description: When failing to understand the intentions of another vessel, or in doubt whether she is taking sufficient action.

warning_bend.title: Warning in a bend
warning_bend.description: A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction.

restricted_vis_power_making_way.title: PDV making way (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_power_making_way.description: In restricted visibility, a power-driven vessel making way through the water.

restricted_vis_power_stopped.title: PDV stopped (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_power_stopped.description: In restricted visibility, a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way.

restricted_vis_special.title: Special vessel (Sailing, Fishing, RAM...) (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_special.description: Vessels not under command, restricted in ability to maneuver, sailing, fishing, etc. in restricted visibility.
restricted_vis_special.signal: ▬ ● ● (One long, two short blasts at intervals ≤ 2 min)

restricted_vis_towed.title: Towed vessel (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_towed.description: The last vessel of a tow, if manned, in restricted visibility.
restricted_vis_towed.signal: ▬ ● ● ● (One long, three short blasts at intervals ≤ 2 min)

restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.title: Anchored < 100m (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.description: Vessel at anchor, less than 100m in length, in restricted visibility.
restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.signal: 🔔 (Rapid ringing of bell for 5s at intervals ≤ 1 min)

restricted_vis_anchored_gt100.title: Anchored >= 100m (Rest. Vis.)
restricted_vis_anchored_gt100.description: Vessel at anchor, 100m or more in length, in restricted visibility.

pilot.title: Pilot Vessel on duty
pilot.description: Identity signal of a pilot vessel.

beaufort.title: Beaufort Wind Scale
beaufort.description: Relates wind speed to observed conditions at sea and on land.

seaState.3: Large wavelets, crests begin to break
seaState.7: Sea heaps up, white foam from breaking waves
seaState.8: Moderately high waves, crests break into spindrift
seaState.9: High waves, sea begins to roll
seaState.10: Very high waves, sea is white with foam
seaState.12: Air filled with foam and spray

douglas.title: Douglas Sea Scale (Sea and Swell)
douglas.description: Classifies the sea state into two scales: one for the wind sea (local) and another for the swell.

clouds.title: Cloud Types
clouds.description: Classification of clouds according to their altitude and shape.

cirrus.name: Cirrus (Ci)
cirrus.description: White, delicate filaments or narrow bands. Composed of ice crystals. Often indicate fair weather but can precede a warm front.

cirrocumulus.name: Cirrocumulus (Cc)
cirrocumulus.description: Thin, white patch or sheet of cloud without shading, composed of very small elements in the form of grains, ripples. Known as a 'mackerel sky'.

cirrostratus.name: Cirrostratus (Cs)
cirrostratus.description: Transparent, whitish veil of fibrous or smooth appearance. Often produces halo phenomena around the Sun or Moon. Indicate the approach of a warm front.

altocumulus.name: Altocumulus (Ac)
altocumulus.description: White or greyish patch, sheet or layer of cloud, generally with shading. Composed of laminae, rounded masses, rolls, etc. May indicate a change in weather or approaching storms.

altostratus.name: Altostratus (As)
altostratus.description: Greyish or bluish sheet or layer of striated, fibrous or uniform appearance. The Sun or Moon may be visible as if through ground glass. Often precede rain or snow.

nimbostratus.name: Nimbostratus (Ns)
nimbostratus.description: Grey, often dark, cloud layer, diffused by more or less continuously falling rain or snow. Produces continuous precipitation of moderate intensity.

stratus.name: Stratus (St)
stratus.description: Generally grey cloud layer with a fairly uniform base, like fog but not resting on the ground. May give drizzle, ice prisms or snow grains. Typical of stable weather.

stratocumulus.name: Stratocumulus (Sc)
stratocumulus.description: Grey or whitish patch, sheet or layer of cloud which almost always has dark parts. Composed of tessellations, rounded masses, rolls, etc. Rarely produce precipitation, and if so, it is weak.

cumulus.name: Cumulus (Cu)
cumulus.description: Detached clouds, generally dense and with sharp outlines, developing vertically. Their base is flat and greyish, while the top is a brilliant white dome. Associated with fair weather.

cumulonimbus.name: Cumulonimbus (Cb)
cumulonimbus.description: Heavy and dense cloud, with a considerable vertical extent. Associated with thunderstorms, heavy showers, hail and tornadoes. The upper portion is often shaped like an anvil.
